To investigate APC activation in GVHD, we used recipient mice with hematopoietic cells genetically deficient in pathways critical for APC maturation in models in which host APCs are absolutely required.

Consistent with this, in an MHC-mismatched allogenic bone marrow transplantation (alloBMT) model, infusing wild-type (wt) recipient splenic or plasmacytoid DCs can partially restore GVHD to mice with MHC-deficient hematopoietic cells (3, 4).
Such a model would predict that without functional receptors for detecting these bacteria, GVHD would be ameliorated, as is the case for responses against bacteria themselves.

In this study,we report our findings from a comprehensivegenetic approach to assessing these modes of immune recognition using recipient mice with APCs genetically deficient in subsets of the aforementioned pathways in GVHDmodels in which host APCs are absolutely required (2, 8).

Taken together, the results of these studies suggest that GVHD is fundamentally different from most antipathogen responses, tend to counter the prevailing models for GVHD initiation (15), and have implications for strategies to prevent GVHD in the clinic.

Host B71/B72 or IL-12 are not required for CD8-mediated GVHD in the C3H.SW→B6 model.
Stimulation through TLRs has been previously examined in alloBMT models.
Less GVHD was also observed in an MHCmismatched GVHD model when donor BM cells were TLR4 deficient (78).
If radiation-resistant host Tregs modify GVHD in the models we employed (which has not been tested), the absence of TLR stimulation could have diminished their activity thereby augmenting GVHD.
In summary, these studies demonstrate that APC activation pathways that contribute to T cell responses in pathogen models are not required for GVHD induction by host APCs.

Yet, other than decreased liver GVHD in IFNAR12/2 mice, decreased skin and increased small bowel GVHD in IFNAR12/2→wt recipients, and increased skin disease in B71/ B722/2 mice, we did not detect organ-specific differences in GVHD histopathology between any knockout mice and wt controls.

To address this would require crossing the knockouts we employed to RAG2/2 or TCR-deficient backgrounds or breeding them to equivalent knockouts on another background, such as BALB/c, to allow parent→F1 GVHDinducing transplants without conditioning.
At a practical level, it will be difficult to study yet further compound “knockout” mice to test for multilayered redundancy.
